data.title: Italian literature: The Book of the Courtier, The Leopard, Hypnerotomachia Poliphili, Giallo, The Travels of Marco Polo, De mulieribus claris
data.meta_description: Italian literature: The Book of the Courtier, The Leopard, Hypnerotomachia Poliphili, Giallo, The Travels of Marco Polo, De mulieribus claris by Source: Wikipedia - ISBN 10: 1157327672 - ISBN 13: 9781157327677 - Books LLC, Wiki Series - 2011 - Softcover
data.text:
Reseña del editor:

Please note that the content of this book primarily consists of articles available from Wikipedia or other free sources online. Pages: 57. Chapters: The Book of the Courtier, The Leopard, Hypnerotomachia Poliphili, Giallo, The Travels of Marco Polo, De mulieribus claris, De Casibus Virorum Illustrium, Manifesto of Futurist Musicians, Italian Folktales, Academy of Arcadia, Pratica della mercatura, L'huomo di lettere, De vulgari eloquentia, De viris illustribus, Bible translations, Sprezzatura, Ritmo cassinese, Consorzio ICoN, Venetian literature, Il teatro alla moda, Tahar Lamri, Ritmo di Sant'Alessio, Ritmo bellunese, Liber Jani de Procida et Palialoco, Caffè Giubbe Rosse, Gli Asolani, Baptista Malatesta, Ritmo lucchese, Leggenda di Messer Gianni di Procida, Cipollino, Accademia degli Svogliati, Italian poetry, Il Giallo Mondadori, Storia della letteratura italiana, Progetto Babele, Erichtho, Segretissimo, Convivio, Biblioteca Universale Sacro-Profana, Six Memos for the Next Millennium, Festivaletteratura, Le Rime, Venice Literary Biennale. Excerpt: Italian literature is literature written in the Italian language, particularly within Italy. It may also refer to literature written by Italians or in Italy in other languages spoken in Italy, often languages that are closely related to modern Italian. A depiction of Boetius teaching his students (1385). Boetius, a 6th century Christian philosopher, helped keep alive the classic tradition in post-Roman Italy.As the Western Roman Empire declined, the Latin tradition was kept alive by writers such as Cassiodorus, Boethius, and Symmachus. The liberal arts flourished at Ravenna under Theodoric, and the Gothic kings surrounded themselves with masters of rhetoric and of grammar. Some lay schools remained in Italy, and noted scholars included Magnus Felix Ennodius (a pagan poet), Arator, Venantius Fortunatus, Felix the Grammarian, Peter of Pisa, Paulinus of Aquileia, and many others. Italians who were interested in theology...
